thread.title: Shelby County trustee says property tax collections up, but delinquent tax collections a concern
thread.title_full: Shelby County trustee says property tax collections up, but delinquent tax collections a concern

author: Linda A. Moore
title: Shelby County trustee says property tax collections up, but delinquent tax collections a concern
text:
Shelby County's first-quarter property tax revenue collections are up over the same period last year, Trustee David Lenoir said, but delinquent property tax collections are down significantly.
Still, with three quarters left in the fiscal year, which ends June 30, 2016, it's too early for alarm over the delinquent collections, Lenoir said.
Lenoir presented the first-quarter results to the County Commission's budget and finance committee on Wednesday, and the full commission will vote to accept his report on Monday. The fiscal year ends June 30, 2016.
First-quarter property tax collections came in at $38.6 million, an increase of 5.83 percent over the $36.5 million during that same period last year. Most property taxes are paid in December when mortgage companies release the funds and in February, when they're late.
Overall tax collections are expected to come in at $729 million.
However, delinquent collections were down, with $8.5 million collected during the first quarter of fiscal 2016, compared with $11.6 million in fiscal 2015, a decrease of 26.5 percent.
"It causes me a little bit of concern, but my heartburn's not going to flare up until another three or four months, when I see where delinquent collections are," Lenoir said.
Every morning he gets an email showing where his staff's status on collections.
"We're not where we hope to be in delinquent collections. And my folks are working as hard as they can, so I know it's not a function of effort," he said.
It's possible that last year's delinquent collections took care of the low-hanging fruit, making collecting money this year more difficult.
The office holds delinquent taxpayer workshops that are well attended, but now they're bumped up against the folks who are really struggling, he said.
"We're doing everything we can. We're working with them," Lenoir said.
That's how Commissioner Steve Basar views it.
"The economy doing better, people are doing better, that's why collections up. People who were behind have caught up or they're never going to catch up," Basar said.
Lenoir came to the commission intent on making sure it was kept apprised throughout the year on the county's collections.
There was confusion at the end of the budget season, when it was learned that the trustee's office collected $22 million more than had been projected.
It wasn't the first time, he said, his office had come in $20 million ahead of projections, but commissioners seemed unaware of the numbers.
He's glad to see a renewed interest in the quarterly reports.
"Since it got so much conversation, I wanted to remind commissioners that we do these reports every three months," Lenoir said. "I think it just started to take root with commission. That's super encouraging."
